Legal_Issue: Whether the Applicant met the residency requirement under paragraph 5(1)(c) of the Citizenship Act
Application_Facts: Applicant claimed 1096 days of physical presence in Canada within four years preceding application
Court_Ruling: Decision quashed; case remanded for reconsideration by a different Citizenship Judge
Defendant_Behavior: Alleged failure to provide sufficient objective evidence of residency
Grounds_for_Claim: Material factual errors and insufficient justification by Citizenship Judge
Assessment_Factor: Physical presence in Canada for at least 1095 days within four years
Procedural_Issue: Appeal filed under subsection 14(5) of the Citizenship Act
Credibility_Assessment: Undermined due to factual errors in judicial assessment
Application_Basis: Demonstration of 1095 days of physical presence
Evidence_Assessed: Subjective attendance records lacking objective audit trail
Relief_Sought: Grant of citizenship upon proper assessment
Governing_Rule: Applicant must prove 1095 days of physical presence in Canada
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of objective 'audit trail' evidence to support residency claims
Harm_Assessment: Unfair denial of citizenship due to flawed evaluation
Cause_Description: Perceived failure to meet residency requirements despite claimed compliance
Evidence_Handling: Improper discounting of evidence due to misinterpretation of stamps and attendance sheets
Evidence_Issues: Misinterpretation of evidence, lack of corroborating documentation
Residency_Compliance: Allegedly met (1096 days), but not sufficiently proven to judge's satisfaction
Evidence_Assessment: Flawed due to factual errors and lack of objective verification
Decision_Rationale: Factual errors undermined credibility assessment and rendered decision unreasonable
Evidentiary_Issues: Absence of reliable, verifiable documentation to support residency
